entry.title: User Login for External Apps with SAP Cloud Identity Services
entry.content:
Introduction

For developers in the SAP BTP ecosystem, the standard path for authentication involves the SAP Application Router and XSUAA. It's robust and deeply integrated. But what if you need to connect a non-BTP application or simply want to experiment with open standards?

This guide demonstrates how to authenticate a standalone Node.js application directly against SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS) using a standard OpenID Connect (OIDC) flow. You can try this scenario just for 10 min. 

Disclaimer: A Proof-of-Concept, Not a Production BTP Recipe

It's crucial to state this upfront: this approach is for educational and validation purposes. For production applications on SAP BTP, the Approuter/XSUAA model remains the recommended best practice. This method is perfect for learning, prototyping, or integrating external apps.

Part 1: Prerequisites - Setting up SAP CIS and Your Local Environment

Before we write any code, we need to configure our identity provider (CIS) and prepare our local machine.

Step 1: Subscribe to Cloud Identity Services

First, ensure you have a subscription to the Cloud Identity Services application in your BTP subaccount. You can add it via the "Service Marketplace" if you haven't already.

Step 2: Create an OIDC Application in SAP CIS

Navigate to your SAP CIS tenant's administration console. You can typically access this from the "Instances and Subscriptions" page in your BTP subaccount.

  1. In the CIS admin UI(https://<CIS Domain>/admin/), go to Applications & Resources -> Applications.
  2. Click Create Application.
  3. Fill in the application details:
    • Name: localhost-auth-app (or any name you prefer)
    • Type: Non-SAP solution
    • Protocol: OpenID Connect (Select OpenID Connect from the dropdown)
       
  4. Add redirect URL.
    This will reveal the OIDC-specific configuration options. For now, we'll set placeholder values for the URIs.
    • Name : SAP BTP Trial (Whatever you want)
    • Redirect URIs: http://localhost:3000/callback
    • Click Save

Step 3: Collect Your Credentials and Issuer URL

  1. Once the application is saved, CIS will generate the necessary client ID.(Application APIs > Client Authentication)
  2. Please generate new secret, under this section.
    Please select some option(Applicatoin, Application Users, OpenID)
  3. Keep this page open or copy the following values to a safe place:
    • Client ID: A long, unique string.
    • Client Secret: copy and keep it.

       

  4.  Next, you need the Issuer URL. This is the unique URL for your CIS tenant that OIDC clients use for discovery.
    • In the CIS admin UI, navigate to Tenant Settings -> OpenID Connect Configuration.
    • Under Identity Provider Settings, you will find the Issuer URL.
      Copy this URL. It will look something like https://.trial-accounts.ondemand.com. For example: https://afsp7XXXX.trial-accounts.ondemand.com.
      (Or please check the URL you're aceessing CIS Admin URL.)

Part 2: Building the Node.js Application

Now we're ready to build the app.

Step 1: Project Setup

Create a new project folder and initialize it. (Following steps for macOS, there are some differences between macOS and Windows OS.)

# Create project directory and navigate into it 
mkdir cis-oidc-app && cd cis-oidc-app

# Initialize a Node.js project
npm init -y

# Install necessary libraries
npm install express openid-client@5.1.5 dotenv

# Create our application files
touch app.js .env

Note: We are pinning openid-client to a known stable version (5.1.5) to avoid potential issues with newer releases.

Step 2: Configure Environment Variables

Open the .env file and add the credentials you collected from CIS.

# .env file

# Paste the Issuer URL from your CIS tenant's OIDC settings
CIS_ISSUER_URL="https://afsp7XXXX.trial-accounts.ondemand.com"

# Paste the Client ID from your created application in CIS
CLIENT_ID="your-client-id-from-cis"

# Paste the Client Secret from your created application in CIS
CLIENT_SECRET="your-client-secret-from-cis"

# The port our local server will run on
PORT=3000

Step 3: The Complete, Working Code (app.js)

This is the full code. The key fix for the openid.Issuer is not a constructor error is using await Issuer.discover() instead of the old constructor method.

require('dotenv').config();
const express = require('express');
const http = require('http');
// const fs = require('fs');
const { Issuer } = require('openid-client');

const app = express();
const port = process.env.PORT || 3000;

// Environment variables check
console.log('Checking environment variables:');
console.log('CIS_ISSUER_URL:', process.env.CIS_ISSUER_URL);
console.log('CLIENT_ID:', process.env.CLIENT_ID);
console.log('CLIENT_SECRET:', process.env.CLIENT_SECRET ? '*** (configured)' : 'not set');
console.log('PORT:', process.env.PORT);

// HTTPS options
// const httpsOptions = {
//   key: fs.readFileSync('key.pem'),
//   cert: fs.readFileSync('cert.pem')
// };

// Custom Issuer configuration for trial account
async function getCustomIssuer() {
  try {
    console.log('Fetching Issuer configuration...');
    
    const issuer = await Issuer.discover(process.env.CIS_ISSUER_URL);
    console.log('Issuer configuration successful:', issuer.issuer);
    
    return issuer;
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Issuer configuration error:', error);
    throw error;
  }
}

// OIDC client initialization
async function initOIDCClient() {
  try {
    const issuer = await getCustomIssuer();
    
    const client = new issuer.Client({
      client_id: process.env.CLIENT_ID,
      client_secret: process.env.CLIENT_SECRET,
      redirect_uris: [`http://localhost:${port}/callback`],
      response_types: ['code'],
      token_endpoint_auth_method: 'client_secret_basic'
    });
    
    console.log('OIDC client initialized successfully');
    return client;
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Client initialization error:', error);
    throw error;
  }
}

// Authentication flow
app.get('/login', async (req, res) => {
  try {
    console.log('Starting login process...');
    const client = await initOIDCClient();
    const authUrl = client.authorizationUrl({
      scope: 'openid profile email',
      redirect_uri: `http://localhost:${port}/callback`
    });
    
    console.log('Generated authentication URL:', authUrl);
    res.redirect(authUrl);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Login error:', error);
    res.status(500).send(`Initialization error: ${error.message}`);
  }
});

// Callback processing
app.get('/callback', async (req, res) => {
  try {
    console.log('Callback received');
    const client = await initOIDCClient();
    const params = client.callbackParams(req);
    
    console.log('Exchanging token...');
    const tokenSet = await client.callback(
      `http://localhost:${port}/callback`,
      params
    );
    
    console.log('Fetching user information...');
    const userInfo = await client.userinfo(tokenSet);
    console.log('User information retrieved:', userInfo.sub);
    
    res.send(`
      <!DOCTYPE html>
      <html lang="en">
      <head>
        <meta charset="UTF-8">
        <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
        <title>Authentication Successful</title>
        <style>
          body { font-family: Arial, sans-serif; line-height: 1.6; max-width: 800px; margin: 0 auto; padding: 20px; }
          h1 { color: #2e7d32; }
          pre { background: #f5f5f5; padding: 15px; border-radius: 4px; overflow-x: auto; }
          .user-info { background: #e8f5e9; padding: 15px; border-radius: 4px; margin-bottom: 20px; }
          .btn { display: inline-block; padding: 10px 20px; background: #4CAF50; color: white; text-decoration: none; border-radius: 4px; }
        </style>
      </head>
      <body>
        <h1>Authentication Successful!</h1>
        
        <div class="user-info">
          <p><strong>Username:</strong> ${userInfo.name || userInfo.email}</p>
          <p><strong>User ID:</strong> ${userInfo.sub}</p>
        </div>
        
        <h2>User Information:</h2>
        <pre>${JSON.stringify(userInfo, null, 2)}</pre>
        
        <hr>
        <a class="btn" href="/">Back to Home</a>
      </body>
      </html>
    `);
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Callback processing error:', error);
    res.status(500).send(`
      <h1>Authentication Error</h1>
      <p>${error.message}</p>
      <a href="/">Back to Home</a>
    `);
  }
});

// Home page
app.get('/', (req, res) => {
  res.send(`
    <!DOCTYPE html>
    <html lang="en">
    <head>
      <meta charset="UTF-8">
      <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
      <title>SAP CIS Authentication Demo</title>
      <style>
        body { font-family: Arial, sans-serif; line-height: 1.6; max-width: 800px; margin: 0 auto; padding: 40px 20px; text-align: center; }
        h1 { color: #1565c0; }
        .container { background: #e3f2fd; padding: 30px; border-radius: 8px; }
        .btn { display: inline-block; padding: 12px 24px; background: #1565c0; color: white; text-decoration: none; border-radius: 4px; font-size: 18px; margin-top: 20px; }
        .note { background: #fff8e1; padding: 15px; border-radius: 4px; margin-top: 30px; text-align: left; }
      </style>
    </head>
    <body>
      <div class="container">
        <h1>SAP CIS Authentication Demo</h1>
        <p>This demo shows how to authenticate with SAP Cloud Identity Services</p>
        <a class="btn" href="/login">Login with SAP CIS</a>
      </div>
      
      <div class="note">
        <h3>Browser Security Note:</h3>
        <p>If you see a security warning in your browser:</p>
        <ul>
          <li>Chrome: Type "thisisunsafe" in the address bar</li>
          <li>Others: Go to "Advanced Settings" → "Proceed to localhost"</li>
        </ul>
      </div>
    </body>
    </html>
  `);
});

// Development: Skip SSL certificate validation
process.env.NODE_TLS_REJECT_UNAUTHORIZED = '0';

// Start HTTP server
http.createServer(app).listen(port, () => {
  console.log('='.repeat(60));
  console.log(`App running: http://localhost:${port}`);
  console.log(`Login URL: http://localhost:${port}/login`);
  console.log('='.repeat(60));
  
  console.log('\n⚠️ Browser Access Instructions:');
  console.log('1. Go to "http://localhost:3000"');
  console.log('2. For security warnings:');
  console.log('   - Chrome: Type "thisisunsafe" in the address bar');
  console.log('   - Others: Click "Advanced" → "Proceed to localhost"');
});

Step 4: Run the Application

You are now ready to test the entire flow.

  1. Run the server from your terminal:
    node app.js
  2. Open your browser and navigate to http://localhost:3000.

     

  3. Click the "Login with SAP CIS" link.
  4. You will be redirected to the SAP CIS login page after entering your credentials.

     

  5. After successful login, you will be redirected back to your local application, which will display your user information.

     

Conclusion

This experiment successfully proves that SAP Cloud Identity Services is a fully compliant OIDC provider, capable of securing not just BTP-native applications but any external application that speaks open standards. While the Approuter/XSUAA pattern remains the gold standard for integrated BTP solutions, it's empowering to have this flexibility for prototyping and external integrations.

I hope this detailed guide helps you connect your own applications.

Shusei, Sekiya

entry.title: Q2 2025: Quarterly Release Highlights: SAP BTP Security and Identity & Access Management
entry.content:
In the second quarter of 2025, we released several new features and enhancements. Did you know that you can find all new feature announcements for SAP Cloud Identity Services in the SAP Cloud Identity Services Release Notes on the SAP Help Portal?

Let’s take a look at some of our recent highlights!

Identity Provisioning Service: Job log improvements

The Job Execution Outcome is now displayed on the Job Execution Details screen and included in the job notifications. It appears when delta-read jobs and jobs that fail to read entities from the source system affect the deletion of entities in the target system.
For more information, see Monitor Provisioning Job Logs.

You can now download and view the details of all deleted entities by a provisioning job. To enable this, set the property ips.trace.deleted.entity to true.
For more information, see Manage Provisioning Job Logs and List of Properties.

Identity Directory Service and Identity Provisioning Service: Support for extension schemas towards many SAP business applications

We now support a number of extension schemas, including

  • SAP extension schema for groups
  • Extension enterprise schema for users
  • SAP ODM User Schema Support

You can find details in the SAP Cloud Identity Release Notes.

Extension of the Identity Directory’s SCIM API

The Identity Directory API of SAP Cloud Identity Services now returns the termsOfUse and privacyPolicy parameters. For more information, check Identity Directory API.

In addition, we now support application-specific group assignments. You can find details in the SAP Help Portal chapters on Identity Authentication and the Local Identity Directory.

Management of Corporate Identity Providers via API

Tenant administrators can manage corporate identity providers in Identity Authentication via API. It offers endpoints for CRUD operations (GET, POST, PATCH, DELETE) over the corporate identity providers. See SAP Cloud Identity Services Corporate Identity Providers Directory.

Configuration of Password Expiration Reminder

You can configure the system to show a password expiration reminder on the user’s sign-in page. For more information, check Enable Password Expiration Reminder.

Enabling SAP Secure Login Service for SAP GUI with support for Microsoft Windows mandatory profiles

We added support for single sign-on on shopfloor Windows-based computers that are configured to use a mandatory profile. This protects shopfloor computers with a restrictive mandatory profile while still offering single sign-on support for desktop clients of SAP GUI. You can find more information in the SAP Roadmap Explorer.

Cloud Foundry Login Based on JSON Web Tokens (JWTs)

When building CI/CD pipelines, developers are responsible for managing the credentials used by these pipelines for authentication to external systems. This traditionally requires developers to take care of the lifecycle of the credentials, including secure storage and regular rotation of the credentials, which comes with repeated efforts and might be error-prone.

In his latest blog post, Authenticating GitHub Actions Workflows Deploying to the SAP BTP Cloud Foundry Environment with JWTs, Sebastian Ries explains how to authenticate to the SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry environment from a GitHub Actions workflow using GitHub-issued short-lived JSON Web Tokens (JWTs), eliminating the need for manual secret management and enabling secure, efficient CI/CD workflows. 

Want to stay up to date on our services? Join our SAP BTP Security, Single Sign-On for SAP GUI and SAP Cloud Identity Services communities!

entry.title: Understanding Identity and Access Management (IAM) in your SAP Landscape
entry.content:
As companies adopt cloud services, hybrid infrastructures, and mobile workforces, traditional security models no longer hold up. That’s where Identity and Access Management (IAM) steps in as a foundational element of modern cybersecurity strategies.

What is IAM?

IAM, or Identity and Access Management, refers to the set of processes, technologies, and policies that ensure the right individuals—employees, partners, customers—have access to the right resources at the right times for the right reasons. It encompasses how users are authenticated, how their access is granted or revoked, and how their digital identities are managed throughout their lifecycle.

In short, IAM is about answering two key questions:

  • Who are you?
  • What are you allowed to do in the system landscape?

Properly implemented IAM safeguards critical systems and data from unauthorized access, minimizes risk, and supports regulatory compliance. It’s a key enabler for digital transformation!

IAM in the Context of the Secure Operations Map (SOM)

In SAP’s Secure Operations Map (SOM), IAM falls under the User & Identity Management domain. This domain addresses how user identities are created, maintained, and authenticated across enterprise systems. It’s closely tied to both operational efficiency and the ability to secure access in a consistent, auditable way.

This positioning reflects IAM’s importance not just as a security function, but as a business enabler. IAM is a central element for maintaining secure, scalable operations across SAP and non-SAP landscapes.

IAM in the Context of the Secure Operations Map (SOM)

Why is IAM So Crucial Today?

IAM has evolved in response to the shifting landscape of IT security. To understand its current importance, it helps to contrast legacy models with today’s Zero Trust approach.

Legacy Security Model: Perimeter-Based Thinking

Traditionally, enterprise security was focused on protecting the network perimeter. Tools like firewalls, intrusion detection systems, and VPNs were used to keep threats out. The assumption was that anything inside the network could be trusted.

However, this model has several flaws:

  • Insider threats remain unmitigated.
  • It doesn’t scale well to cloud or remote access.
  • Once attackers breach the perimeter, they can move laterally with little resistance.

Zero Trust Security Model: Trust Nothing by Default

In contrast, Zero Trust assumes breach as a baseline. It operates on the principle of “never trust, always verify.” In this model:

  • Every user and device must authenticate continuously.
  • Access is granted based on identity, context, and least privilege.
  • Identity becomes the new security perimeter.

This is why modern IAM is more than just a directory or a login page—it's the core of Zero Trust architecture.

Identity becomes the new security perimeter

SAP Cloud Identity Services (SCI): Your IAM Gateway

Within the SAP ecosystem, the primary tool for IAM is SAP Cloud Identity Services (SCI). SCI is not just a technical necessity—it’s a strategic enabler that helps organizations innovate faster and more securely.

What is SAP Cloud Identity Services?

SAP Cloud Identity Services is a suite of cloud-based solutions designed to provide seamless, secure, and scalable identity management across SAP and third-party applications. Its key components are:

  • Identity Authentication Service (IAS): Handles user login and Single Sign-On (SSO), with support for modern authentication protocols like SAML, OAuth, and OpenID Connect.
  • Identity Provisioning Service (IPS): Automates the creation, update, and removal of user accounts across connected systems. Reduces manual effort and risk of human error.
  • Identity Directory: Stores user attributes and acts as a central repository for identity data, enabling fine-grained control over access.
  • Authorization Management: Helps to define and manage fine-grained access policies for SAP BTP applications based on user or business object attributes. Assign policies using group management in the identity directory, either via SAP Cloud Identity Services UI or the SCIM API.

Together, these services allow organizations to unify identity management across cloud, hybrid, and on-premise systems—accelerating time-to-value while improving compliance and security.

SAP IAM integration with SAP Cloud Identity Services

How to Get Started with IAM in SAP?

If you're new to IAM or just beginning your journey with SAP Cloud Identity Services, here’s a roadmap to guide you:

  • Explore the IAM Reference Architectures: Understand the big picture by reviewing SAP’s recommended architectures for IAM: IAM Reference Architectures

  • Get Hands-On with Tutorials: Try out SCI in a test environment to see how provisioning works in practice. You can also start with a mission on SAP discovery center https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/missiondetail/3116/3152/

  • Collaborate Across Teams: IAM is not a siloed effort. Talk to your Identity & Access Management colleagues and align on strategies for integrating supported systems. Supported Systems in SCI

  • Involve Experts Early: IAM often reaches beyond the SAP center of competence into enterprise architecture, HR systems, compliance, and even customer experience. Bring in experts who can help you design processes that are secure, user-friendly, and scalable.

Final Thoughts

Implementing IAM is not just about ticking a compliance box or improving login flows. It’s about protecting your organization’s most valuable assets—its data, systems, and people—while enabling agility and innovation.

IAM is a journey, not a one-time project. As you build your foundation with SAP Cloud Identity Services, keep in mind that success depends on both technical integration and cross-functional collaboration.

The important IAM domain of secure authentication will be covered in my next post, where I’ll  share practical tips on how to ensure secure connection works both in cloud and on premises.

entry.title: What's New in SAP BTP – Q2 2025
entry.content:
Q2 was another big quarter for SAP Business Technology Platform. From application development to integration and analytics, we are excited to share how SAP BTP continues to simplify, streamline, and speed things up! Let's dive into some of the top innovations!

App Dev & Automation Highlights 

Simplified SAPUI5 extensions with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard 

If your business relies on cloud ERP as its IT backbone, you know it may need extensions to meet unique requirements. When built-in extensibility isn’t enough, SAP Build on SAP BTP offers powerful options for custom coding and SAP Fiori UI extensions.  

Now, with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard, you can create UI extensions directly from your cloud ERP application. By launching the Extensibility Wizard directly from your SAP Fiori application, you are given different options for the type of extension you want to create.

The 'User Interface Extension' lets you either adapt the existing Fiori app or create a new custom application. By setting up your destinations and details in the Wizard, you can either remove sections, add new fields, and create a completely new variant of the application with SAP Build Code and Business Application Studio. Developers and key users can already use it to create custom processes and now, custom user interfaces. 

Watch the video demo (starting at 0:08)  for more insights!   

Learn more:  Simplify SAPUI5 Code Extensions with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard

Application to Enable Business Users to Manage Decisions

To empower business users to view or maintain decisions within SAP Build Process Automation, we launched a dedicated, purpose-built application that can be accessed directly from SAP Build Work Zone – without the need of IT. 

Business users can access a dedicated application in SAP Build Work Zone to manage decisions within a single project. Users can open the decision table, modify values directly, or import data from Excel and then save their changes, seeing only what matters and making the experience clean and focused. The release of a changed version is only one click away. Any errors are shown in the design console, letting users view the different versions of the project. 

See for yourself in the demo (starting at 2:05)  for more insights!

Learn more 

  • Configure the Stuido Home Application 
  • Using the Studio Home Application

Partner Solutions as an Installable Product on SAP BTP ABAP Environment 

Good news for SAP partners developing apps with SAP BTP ABAP Environment: you can now offer your solution not only as a multitenant Software as a Service solution, but also as an installable product! 

Customers can now install the solution directly in their system as a product. As a part of SAP BTP ABAP Environment, the Landscape Portal supports both delivery options: multitenant SaaS and installable product. 

You can do this in three easy steps:

  1. Build your product with the Register Product app. 
  2. Choose your delivery model: 
    • For multitenant SaaS, configure it in the Maintain Solution app  
    • For installable product, use the Publish Product app. 
  3. Publish your solution to the SAP Store with a PartnerEdge Build contract and an SAP Store enhancement. 

Now customers using SAP BTP ABAP Environment can find your product in the SAP Store and install it into their own system using the Deploy Product option. 

For detailed guidance, watch the demo (starting at 3:42). 

Learn more: Building partner products on SAP BTP ABAP Environment

Integration Highlight

Describe Externalized Parameters of an Integration Flow 

In SAP Integration Suite externalization enables integration developers to define parameters as variables for certain configurations of adapters or flow steps of an integration flow. The values of these parameters can be changed without editing the integration flow, for example, when moving integrations from development or test environment to production. To simplify the understanding of this difficult and technical process, content developers can now provide descriptions directly in the integration flow editor. These can be the potential values, examples or additional details explaining the impact of specific values which will then be visible for guiding through each of the fields in the Configure view. This brings huge potential to improve the maintainability and reusability of your integration scenarios.  

Take a look at the demo (starting at 5:21) and see for yourself! 

Learn more: Externalized Parameters View

Data & Analytics Highlight

Analytical insights in Joule 

Joule, SAP's copilot, now enables you to get quick analytical answers without having to build reports. This provides you with valuable insights, saving time and giving you the information you need. 

Joule scans available data sources and suggests a few options, making comparisons to previous months easier. Joule updates the view right away, making it easy to see how things are trending. For example, you can ask for the top ten sales agents, check the monthly commission trend from January to March, giving you contextual and relevant answers 

See this in action in the demo (starting 7:15).

Learn more: Introducing Analytical Insights in Joule: Empowering Smarter Decisions, Instantly

Cross Platform Highlight

Provision App-Specific Groups in Identity Directory 

SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant enables immediate provisioning of authorizations to target systems in SAP Analytics Cloud target system. You can  centrally manage user-group assignments linked to application-specific policies, triggering provisioning jobs that synchronize access rights efficiently and securely. This ensures users gain prompt access to their designated roles in the target system.

Watch the demo (starting at 8:37) for a closer look. 

Learn more: SAP Cloud Identity Services

Share your thoughts 

These videos are for YOU. We would love to hear your impressions. How do you like the video? How can we improve the upcoming videos? Please share your feedback by liking this post or leaving a comment below.

Thank you for your support and happy viewing, sharing, and enjoying!

You Might Also Be Interested In

  • SAP BTP Garage: monthly LIVE webinar with hands-on use case walkthroughs and demos.
  • SAP BTP Talk Podcast: monthly podcast covering all things SAP BTP.

entry.title: Configure Single-Sign-On for SAP Ariba with SAP Cloud Identity Services
entry.content:
See as well:
  • Summary: SAP Ariba, SAP Business Network, SAP Fieldglass SSO with SAP IAS
  • Overview: SAP Ariba SSO with SAP Cloud Identity Services - Identity Authentication

Abstract

With the introduction in 2505 release of the feature 'Configure Authentication with SAP Cloud Identity Services for SAP Ariba Solutions in Intelligent Configuration Manager (CFG-324)' , Single-Sign-On (SSO) configuration for SAP Ariba with SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS) is simplified and further automated, as detailed in this blog post.

Prerequisites

  • SAP Ariba user of type Third Party Enterprise User (Ariba)
  • Customer Administrator group membership
  • S-User ID in SAP for Me

Note: It is strongly recommended to use https as the SAP Ariba SSO SAML 2.0 Issuer, for security reason and for alignment with the auto-generated configuration described below. A support ticket requesting  PS-1444 Feature Toggle is required to enable the use of https in the issuer.

Process

1. Access SAP Ariba Intelligent Configuration Manager (ICM)

Access the SAP Ariba tenant using the Third Party Enterprise User (Ariba) created as part of the prerequisites.

  • Build the login URL appending '?passwordadapter=ThirdPartyUser' to use Third Party User authentication. For example for US Datacenter: https://<SAP Ariba tenant id>.procurement.ariba.com?passwordadapter=ThirdPartyUser
  • Open ICM - Navigate to Manage > Core Administration (for SAP Ariba procurement tenant) / Administration (for SAP Ariba sourcing tenants) > Intelligent Configuration Manager > Manage Configurations > Click Continue button
  • Open the Authentication tab of ICM

 

Note: In case of configuring the SSO setup for SAP Ariba Sourcing, SAP Ariba Contracts, SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance for suite-integrated tenants the SSO setup needs to be executed on the SAP Ariba procurement tenant.

In case of  SAP Ariba Multi-ERP configuration setup (f.k.a Federated Process Control FPC) the SSO configuration needs to happen for the parent tenant. 

2. S-User ID configuration

The S-User ID must be linked to the same organization as the SAP Ariba tenant (and CIS tenant to use if already provisioned), this can be verified by opening the System & Provisioning section of the SAP4Me portal, connected with the S-User and validating that the SAP Ariba tenant (and CIS Tenant if already provisioned) appear as in the below example with SAP Ariba Procurement and provisioned CIS Tenant.

 

 

  • Enter the S-User ID and click Validate - The validation process takes around a minute and requires page refresh to update the status

 

  • Once validated, use the Enable button to enable the site for CIS configuration

 

3. CIS Tenant selection

Depending on the landscape two paths are available :

  • CIS tenant Provisioning - In case no CIS tenant is available, provisioning of a CIS tenant is done from ICM and then auto-configured.
  • CIS tenant Selection - In case CIS tenants are already available, tenant selection is needed for the auto-configuration.

3.a. CIS Tenant Provisioning

Validate and submit the tenant provisioning form generated from the S-User information data.

 

3.b. CIS Tenant Selection

Select the appropriate CIS tenant for auto configuration from the list and submit.

 

Note : Landscape tier alignment is required ie: If SSO is configured on a Test SAP Ariba tenant, selection of CIS with tenant type Test is required, and similarly with Production.

4. Approval

Upon CIS tenant provisioning request (3a) or CIS tenant selection (3b) an approval is required to trigger auto-configuration.

 

  

5. Auto-Configure CIS

Auto configuration process runs upon tenant provisioning / selection showing 'Provisioning in Progress' status, it takes several minutes and generates several artefacts in CIS:

  • SAML Applications Configuration with the SAP Ariba tenant for user authentication over SSO
  • OpendID Applications Configuration with the SAP Ariba tenant for app-to-app connectivity
  • Source and Target systems in Identity Provisioning Service for user and group provisioning

Note : Auto-configuration leverages by default the Login Name attribute of the CIS user as NameID for the SAML assertion, therefore it needs to match the UniqueName attribute of the SAP Ariba user.

 

Note : The Configuration step creates several applications in the CIS tenant with dedicated pattern. In case of a Suite Integrated tenant with Multi-ERP the applications are defined as below:

Parent Realm :

  • Application for SSO on the Parent realm with normalized name <Customer name><SAP Ariba Procurement parent realm name>
  • Applications for app-to-app authentication with normalized names: Sourcing-<SAP Ariba Sourcing realm id> and Procurement-<SAP Ariba Procurement parent realm id>

Child Realm :

  • Application for SSO on the Child realm with normalized name <Customer name><SAP Ariba Procurement child realm name>
  • Application for app-to-app authentication with normalized name  : Procurement-<SAP Ariba Procurement child realm id>

 

6. Activate Configuration

Once auto-configured the system is in 'Ready to Activate' state, click the Activate button to enable SSO.

Confirm configuration acknowledgements.

 Note: Once Activated, SSO configuration cannot be deactivated from ICM, in case deactivation or configuration change is required, a support ticket needs to be raised.

Note: In case any of the SSO setup steps from S-User validation (Validate or Enable), from Approval (Approve) or from Auto-Configuration activation (Activate) takes more than 3 hours, an incident needs to be created against the BNS-ARI-RSK-ICM component.

 

7. Test Configuration

Once activated, the SSO configuration is enabled and can be validated:

7.a ICM

ICM configuration should show Activated CIS as well as Enabled SAML Authentication.

 

7.b SAP Ariba web interface access

Access SAP Ariba tenant via its URL in a web browser - for example for US Datacenter: https://<SAP Ariba tenant id>.procurement.ariba.com

Redirection to the configured CIS tenant login page validates correct setup.

 

Redirection to the SAP Ariba login page denotes an issue with SSO configuration.

 

Note : In case of  SAP Ariba Multi-ERP configuration setup, test both the Parent and Children accesses.

Remarks

Note: In case Third-Party SAP Ariba users need to be authenticated by the Identity Provider setup for SAP Ariba SSO, PLAF-1869 Feature Toggle needs to be enabled via a support ticket. Ensure you have the proper Third-Party SAP Ariba users setup in your Identity Provider setup for SAP Ariba SSO as your existing SAP Ariba credentials for Third-Party SAP Ariba users will not be working after the Feature Toggle is enabled. In case of issues accessing SAP Ariba for Third-Party SAP Ariba users via Identity Provider setup for SAP Ariba SSO ask to disable PLAF-1869 Feature Toggle to revert back to the SAP Ariba authentication of Third-Party SAP Ariba users.

Note: In case SSO was configured on the SAP Ariba tenant with CIS prior to the CFG-324 feature release, it is currently not possible to leverage this process, this blog will be update when more information will be available.

 

See as well:
  • Summary: SAP Ariba, SAP Business Network, SAP Fieldglass SSO with SAP IAS
  • Overview: SAP Ariba SSO with SAP Cloud Identity Services - Identity Authentication

entry.title: Navigating the Future: Understanding Upcoming Changes to SAP Universal ID
entry.content:
As digital transformation continues to reshape businesses worldwide, identity and user management have become more critical than ever. In this landscape, SAP is evolving how it approaches user identity through significant changes to the SAP Universal ID (UID) framework. These changes reflect SAP’s ongoing commitment to streamlining user experiences while enhancing security across its platforms.

One of the most notable updates: users will no longer log in using their UID. Instead, authentication will now require an email address and a dedicated password. While the UID itself will no longer be used for login anymore, it will continue to serve as an umbrella technology, efficiently collecting and managing all accounts linked under a single UID email address.

This updated authentication process represents a more simplified approach to SAP identity management. This blog post will explore the current state of SAP Universal ID, highlight the recent changes, explain their impact on users, and outline what’s next for the future of SAP identity management.

What Is SAP Universal ID?  

SAP Universal ID (UID) was created to serve as a unified account across all SAP systems, managing and linking various user IDs such as S-, P-, C-, D-, and I-user IDs into one seamless account. This consolidation not only simplified access but also ensured that learning certificates, awards, and reputation badges are retained permanently, regardless of organizational changes.

What's Changing in SAP Universal ID? 

Looking ahead to August 2025, important changes are going to happen to SAP Universal ID. This transition removes UID as a login method and positions it purely as a management tool. Users will no longer authenticate using their UID. Instead, the UID will function solely as a "wallet", enabling users to link and manage all their user identities in the SAP UID Account Manager. Authentication will be handled through these linked accounts, not the UID itself. These broader identity renovation strategy advancements underscore SAP’s commitment to simplifying the user experience across its platforms by creating a more unified, secure, and user-friendly login experience across the SAP ecosystem.

Why Is SAP Making This Change? 

This transformation is part of SAP’s broader identity renovation strategy. As SAP continues to evolve its identity and management solutions, the transition to identity renovation represents a new chapter in digital identity consolidation and management. While SAP Universal ID remains a pivotal part of this strategy, the shift towards SAP IAS sessions highlights the dynamic nature of enterprise technology. For customers and partners understanding and adapting to these changes will ensure optimized digital interactions within the SAP ecosystem. 

The SAP Universal ID will shift roles with the advent of identity renovation. You can learn more about it in the Bring Your Own Identity: SAP's Strategic Transformation of Identity and Authentication Management blog post.

entry.title: Connect to Public Cloud API in Node.js via Authorisation Code
entry.content:
Connecting to a Public Cloud API (from Business Accelerator Hub) via Node.js CAP application can be challenging. I hope this blog helps others attempting the same task.

 Prerequisites

• SAP BTP subaccount (Cloud Foundry)
• Service key for the target Public Cloud API
• XSUAA instance bound to your CAP app
• SAP BTP Destination service instance
• Bruno installed for manual testing

 

1. Confirm the API's Auth Options

First, check which authentication methods are available for the API you plan to consume.

In my example I connect to the Specification Management API, but the steps apply to any Public Cloud API.

If the OAuth 2.0 Access Code Flow is listed under “Authentication Methods”, the API supports the authorization-code flow. That flow confirms a user context and usually grants wider authorisations, such as update and POST requests.

(OAuth 2.0 Application Flow corresponds to the client-credentials flow.)

2. Connect manually with Bruno (Good blog on Bruno)

Because our API supports the auth-code flow, we first prove we can log in by calling it via Bruno.

Create a new collection and paste the base URI of your Public Cloud API instance (you’ll find it in the service key in your service instance of the saas application your connecting to).

When you send a test GET request you will probably receive an authorisation error. Configure OAuth 2.0 on the Auth tab

Select Grant type Authorisation Code

Then fill in the below fields using your service key from your service instance

  • Callback URL: <your Public Cloud API hostname>
  • Auth URL:** https://<subdomain>.authentication.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/authorize
  • Access-Token URL: https://<subdomain>.authentication.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token
  • Client ID / Secret: from the uaa section of the service key

Request the token, pick your identity provider, and Bruno will return an access token. Inspect the scopes there to see what you can do.

3. Connect to the API from Node.js

After the manual check we can now automate the flow in a Node.js service.

3.1 Destination setup

Create a destination that points to the same API endpoint and bind it to your app.

The required scopes and the audience (aud) value are visible inside the Bruno access token.

the Audience should start with the client id of your CAP application on BTP

Once the destination is saved, ensure your application is bound to the Destination service.

3.2 xs-security.json

Add every scope your service needs so the approuter, it will forward it in the user’s JWT: in my example i needed this scope.

{
  "name": "$XSAPPNAME.Spc_Write",
  "description": "Allow modification of specifications."
}

Also reference the scope in authorities (and role templates, if used) and assign the resulting role collection to your user.

3.3 Connect in code

Now time to connect to the API in the code itself.

First, obtain the user’s JWT. This helper below tries every possible source and falls back to LOCAL_USER_JWT in local development:

/** Try every source for a JWT and fall back to LOCAL_USER_JWT. */
function getJwt(capReq) {
  // CAP ≥ 7.3 keeps the raw token here
  if (capReq.user?.jwt) return capReq.user.jwt;

  // Plain HTTP / WebSocket headers
  const hdrs = capReq.http?.req?.headers || {};
  const token =
        hdrs['x-approuter-authorization'] ||   // CF WebSocket
        hdrs.authorization;                    // CF HTTP

  if (token) return token.replace(/^Bearer\s+/, '');
  // Last resort for local dev
  return process.env.LOCAL_USER_JWT;
}

3.3.1 Testing locally

When testing locally we don't have access to the user JWT so we can add it manually to the environment file so we can still test locally, below is the process to get the JWT for user testing (each token lasts about 7 to 8 hours)

Step 1 – Get an auth code
https://<instance>.eu10.authentication.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/authorize
?response_type=code
&client_id=<XSUAA client id of your deployed app>
&redirect_uri=http://localhost
&state=xyz

Paste your version into your browsers address bar, after login you will land on http://localhost/?code=<AUTH_CODE>&state=xyz. Copy the value of AUTH_CODE.

Step 2 – Exchange the code for a JWT

I made the Curl Request inside BAS itself. it will return a number of tokens, we only need the first and biggest one.

curl -v -X POST \
-u '<same client id>' \
--data-urlencode grant_type=authorization_code \
--data-urlencode code=<AUTH_CODE> \
--data-urlencode redirect_uri=http://localhost \
https://<instance>.eu10.authentication.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token

Save the token from the response into .env:

LOCAL_USER_JWT=<paste JWT here>

3.3.2 Call the destination with the JWT

const jwt = getJwt(req);
if (!jwt) req.reject(401, 'No user token found.');

const dest = await getDestination({
  destinationName: '<DestinationName>',
  jwt
});
await executeHttpRequest(dest, {
  method: 'POST',
  url: `/odata/v4/api/specification/v1/${EntityName}`,
  data: v
});

If you reach the destination but receive 401 Unauthorized, your JWT is missing the correct scope—ask the product team which one you need.

Other common pitfall is using the different XSUAA instances to get your JWT for the local run. use your applications XSUAA client since this is the same one your application will check the token against

And that’s it! You should now be able to read from and write to the Public Cloud API. For read-only workloads the client-credentials flow is usually simpler.

If I missed anything or you’d like more details, please comment below—happy to help.

 

## Frequently Asked Questions

### What’s the difference between authorization-code and client-credentials flows?
The authorization-code flow runs in a user context, so it can carry user-level scopes (read, write, update). The client-credentials flow operates with a technical user—perfect for background jobs or read-only integrations.

### Why do I get “401 Unauthorized” after deployment?
Your user’s JWT is probably missing the required scope (e.g., `Spc_Write`). Make sure the scope is listed in xs-security.json, mapped to a role template, and assigned via a role collection in the BTP cockpit.

### Which audience value belongs in my destination?
Use the client ID of your CAP application’s XSUAA instance; it usually starts with `sb-<appName>!t<number>`.

entry.title: Integrating SAP CIS with SAP SuccessFactors: A Guide to Standard and Hybrid Integration
entry.content:
Overview

SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS) is a robust suite of tools designed to manage identity and access across the SAP ecosystem. This blog explores how CIS integrates with SAP SuccessFactors, focusing on hybrid integration patterns that enable seamless user authentication and identity provisioning in complex enterprise landscapes.

There are three primary flavors to integrating

  1. Standard Integration (Recommended)
  2. Proxy Integration using CIS(external IDP as authentication provider)
  3. Hybrid Integration using CIS (external IDP or both external IDP and CIS as authentication provider) without SF being the source of user records to CIS

 SAP SuccessFactors with SAP Cloud Identity Services:

Option 1: Integration Between SAP SuccessFactors and SAP CIS (Standard)

This is the most recommended method, fully aligned with SAP’s best practices for managing user identities. It involves the following steps:

  1. Integrate SAP SuccessFactors with Identity Authentication: Run the upgrade job in the SAP SuccessFactors Upgrade Center to enable features and establish trust between SF and CIS.
  2. Confirm that user sync is set up in Identity Provisioning in SAP Cloud Identity Services: Set up sync jobs with Identity Provisioning. Ensure that the user that is configured in the Identity Provisioning
  3. Review the default configurations: Review the default configuration of the Identity Authentication service to determine if it meets your requirements or if additional configuration is required.
  4. Additional configuration optional features:Configuration options in Identity Authentication include:  Password policy settings, Single sign-on (SSO) etc
  5. Activate Identity Authentication (IAS): Turn on the Identity Authentication service

This ensures standardized, low-effort configuration and a consistent integration experience. More Details - SAP Help

Option 2: Using SAP CIS as a Proxy (Standard)

Many enterprises already use external identity providers (e.g., Azure AD, Okta) and want to continue doing so while adopting SAP applications.

By integrating the external IdP with CIS, organizations can:

  • Maintain centralized identity governance.
  • Enable secure authentication across SAP SuccessFactors, SAC, and Joule.

In this approach CIS acts as a proxy and user authentication is taken care by the external Identity provider like Entra, OKTA, etc. CIS may/may not have user records in its internal store (based on your requirements). Federation can be used if user records exist. Synching user records in CIS unlock features like SAC and future innovations such as SAP Joule, as they're a key prerequisite for access. Ideal for customers wanting minimal disruption to existing identity infrastructure while gaining access to SAP’s innovation roadmap.

Option 3: Hybrid Integration — Using SAP CIS as a Proxy Without Standard SF User Sync.

Further details in this blog primarily focuses on this hybrid model.

Key Characteristics:

  • SAP SuccessFactors is not the user provisioning source.
  • CIS can act as a proxy or both proxy and IDP
  • User profile data is synced to CIS from a different /external source to enable:
    • Access to services like SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) and SAP Joule
    • Federated authentication via external IdPs

This method provides the flexibility to maintain external Identity manager to keep managing users in an enterprise while using SAP CIS to enabling access to SAP applications and to access new features and innovations.

⚙️Understanding Standard Integration Behavior

SAP’s standard SF-to-CIS integration includes two background jobs(in case if SAC exist):

Job 1: User Sync from SuccessFactors to IAS

  • Reads user data from SF.
  • Creates users in CIS.
  • Generates a Global User ID, and store it in personKeyNav/GlobalUserId in SF.
  • Populates CustomAttribute1 if the user has SAC access permissions.

Job 2: Sync to SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

  • Reads user data from SF and syncs only users with access to embedded analytics to SAC
  • Prevents SAC user creation for ineligible accounts.

⚙️Adapting the Integration for an External Data Source

If you're not syncing users from SAP SF (i.e., using an external Data source like Identity manager), the standard jobs need to be customized to use IAS as the source and SAC as the target. It is very important to make sure that only users who have permission to embedded analytics should be synched to SAC. This step can be done either inside the cync job or can be taken care at source level (making sure to populate the custom attribute only if user has permission to access SAC)

⚠️To configure this job, you can modify the existing target or create a new one. If creating a new target, an SAP support ticket is required to set credentials (OAuth token URL, Client ID, and Secret).

📋Step-by-Step: Hybrid Integration with External Source

  1. Integrate SAP SuccessFactors with Identity Authentication: Run the upgrade job in the SAP SuccessFactors Upgrade Center to enable features and establish trust between SF and CIS.
  2. Review the default configurations: Review the default configuration of the Identity Authentication service to determine if it meets your requirements or if additional configuration is required.
  3. Create Admin User for SCIM Access: Use SCIM APIs to push user records from the external system.
  4. Retain Global User ID (Optional): If needed, set the Global User ID in CIS to a unique external ID or let the system generate one. This Global User Id needs to be updated in SF at (personKeyNav/GlobalUserId).
  5. Sync to SAC
    Run a custom job (IAS → SAC) to:
    • Check SAC access rights.
    • Create users accordingly.

⚙️ Addressing Common Technical Challenges in Hybrid Integration

1: Managing Different Subject Name Identifiers (SNI) Across Applications

In hybrid, multi-application environments, it's common for login identifiers to vary across systems. SAP CIS supports multiple Subject Name Identifiers (SNI) per application, allowing flexibility. For scenarios where CIS login name is taken by another application as the identifier and it doesn't have the same value as username in SF then any other field supported field can be used for SNI. 

For SAP SuccessFactors (SF), it's essential to ensure that the runtime value of the SNI must align with the SF username field to enable proper user identification.

Note: Expression-based SNI mapping is supported, but functionality is currently limited. Use with caution and review configuration thoroughly before implementation

2: Can SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) Work Without a Direct Sync from SF to CIS?

Yes, Though it is recommended to sync it from SF SAC does not require a direct user synchronization from SF. However, there's a critical requirement to enable user access:

Ensure CustomAttribute1 is correctly populated, as it is used to determine analytics access. Regardless of the data source, this attribute must be synced to SAC via CIS.

3: Can CustomAttribute1 Be Replaced with Another Attribute?

Absolutely. CustomAttribute1 is just a label. In SAP CIS, custom attributes are internally stored as an array, offering flexibility in how they're used.

If you choose to use a different custom attribute:

  • Ensure the transformation logic is updated accordingly, to confirm that consuming applications (e.g., SAC) are configured to read the new attribute.

  • Update the SNI mapping to reference the correct custom attribute.

4: Connecting Multiple SF Tenants to a Single CIS Tenant (with SAC for Each SF)

While technically possible, connecting multiple SuccessFactors tenants to the same CIS tenant, each with its own SAC instance, but it is not recommended. This setup introduces significant complexity in Managing user states across tenants.    

Conclusion

Integrating SAP SuccessFactors with SAP Cloud Identity Services offers flexibility, security, and alignment with SAP’s innovation roadmap. Whether through standard integration or a hybrid identity landscape using external IdPs, these methods empower organizations to centralize access control, reduce redundancy, and prepare for emerging technologies like SAP Joule.

entry.title: SAP Build Process Automationで「グループ宛て承認ワークフロー」を構築する
entry.content:
はじめに

SAP Build Process Automation（SBPA）は、ノーコードで業務プロセスを素早く自動化できる強力なツールです。
本記事では、SAP Cloud Identity Services – Identity Authentication (以下、SAP IAS)で定義したユーザーグループを宛先として、複数のユーザーに対して承認依頼を送るプロセスの構築手順を、画面キャプチャとともに紹介します。

ステップ①：SAP IASでユーザーグループを作成・設定する

まず、承認先となるユーザーグループをSAP IASの管理画面から作成します。

1. グループの作成

SAP IAS管理画面で「Create Group」から新しいグループを作成します。

  • Name / Display Name：Demo_Managers
  • Description：マネージャー用のユーザーグループ

2. アプリケーションとの関連付け

このグループをSAP Build Process Automationに紐づけます。

  • Application：SAP Build Process Automation
  • Group Type：userGroup
  • Supported Operations：readWrite

3. 内容を確認し、「Finish」で確定

 

ステップ②：グループにユーザーをアサインする

承認を担当するユーザーをグループに追加します。ここでは、マネージャーAとマネージャーBをアサインしています。

これで、SAP Build Process Automationからこのグループを指定して承認依頼を送る準備が整いました。

ステップ③：申請フォーム（startForm）を作成する

次に、申請者が入力するフォームをSAP Build Process Automationで作成します。

フォーム構成：

  • 送付先グループ（ドロップダウン）
    • 値：Demo_Managers / Demo_Finance / Demo_HR（今回は手動定義とします）
    • 必須：ON
  • 備考（テキストエリア）

テストの目的で、申請者がどのグループに依頼を出すかを選べる構成とします。

ステップ④：承認フォーム（ApprovalForm）を作成する

承認者が内容を確認し、処理するための画面を作成します。

  • 備考欄を表示（読み取り専用）
  • 「承認」「却下」ボタン

ステップ⑤：ワークフローを構築する

フォームが完成したら、ワークフロー全体を組み立てます。

プロセス構成：

  1. Trigger（startForm）
  2. Approvalステップ（ApprovalForm）
  3. 承認/却下の分岐
  4. End

承認ステップの設定：

  • Approval Form：ApprovalForm
  • Recipients > Groups：startFormの「送付先グループ」の値をバインド

ステップ⑥：実行と挙動の確認

1. 申請画面（申請者がグループを選択して送信）

2. 承認者A/BのInboxにタスクが届く

マネージャーAのInbox画面

マネージャーBのInbox画面

申請はグループ全員に配信され、誰か1人が対応すれば完了です。

ちなみに、画面右下にある「Claim」ボタンを使えば、タスクを「自分が担当します」と宣言できます。Claimされたタスクは他のメンバーのInboxから非表示になり、二重対応の防止や担当の明確化に役立ちます。

承認者Bにより「Claim」されると、他の承認者のInboxからは承認タスクが見えなくなります。

まとめ

SAP Build Process AutomationとSAP IASを連携することで、ユーザーグループ単位での柔軟な承認フローをノーコードで構築できます。
以下の流れでステップバイステップに対応可能です：

  1. SAP IASでグループを作成し、ユーザーをアサイン
  2. SAP Build Process Automationで申請フォームと承認フォームを作成
  3. グループに対してしたワークフローを構築
  4. グループに属する誰かが処理できる

業務チームや部門単位での柔軟な承認プロセス設計に、ぜひご活用ください。

entry.title: Identity and Access Management in SAP: Navigating SSO Across Web and On-Prem Landscapes
entry.content:
As explained in my latest post, managing Identity and Access Management (IAM) in SAP environments  is more crucial than ever. Beyond simply improving user experience, effective IAM ensures secure and consistent authentication mechanisms across both cloud and on-premise systems. At the heart of this strategy lies SAP Cloud Identity Services (SCI)—the go-to solution for centralized identity management and streamlined Single Sign-On (SSO) in the SAP ecosystem.

SCI serves as the central interface for managing identity and access across SAP solutions. It plays a foundational role in enabling SSO while enforcing authentication policies uniformly across the landscape. Within the Secure Operations Map (SOM), SSO is positioned squarely in the "Authentication and Single Sign-On" domain, underlining its critical role in maintaining secure and reliable access throughout your SAP systems.

Authentication in the Context of the Secure Operations Map (SOM)

One Authentication Experience Across Web and On-Premise

A key advantage of SCI is its ability to support both cloud-based and on-premise authentication scenarios. For browser-based applications, SCI supports modern protocols such as SAML 2.0 and OpenID Connect (OIDC). These standards are widely adopted across the SAP ecosystem and allow organizations to integrate with various identity providers while benefiting from centralized policy enforcement. For those navigating protocol choices, you can explore the comparison further in this blog post.

When it comes to authentication to on-premise applications, things work differently. These clients communicate via Remote Function Calls (RFC) rather than HTTP, which means traditional SAML or OIDC-based SSO methods don’t apply. To extend SSO capabilities here, SAP recommends using Secure Login Client in combination with Secure Login Service (SLS). This setup leverages short-lived X.509 certificates that are issued based on SCI-authenticated identities. The benefit of this approach is that it allows organizations to reuse the same Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) mechanisms you’ve implemented for web applications, ensuring a seamless and secure user experience across all access channels.

Single sign-on based on X.509 certificates – Process flow

There are other options than using short lived certificates via SLS available as well. Organizations can opt for Kerberos tokens, which are especially suitable for Windows-based environments, or deploy local short-lived client certificates.

For those seeking a more technical view of how these components interact, SAP offers a reference architecture for authentication, including SCI’s integration with both cloud and on-premise systems.

Authentication Reference Architecture

What’s Next: From Access Risks to Business Risks

With the fundamentals of access management and SSO in place, the next step is to examine broader business risks in your SAP landscape. In upcoming posts, we’ll shift focus to how these risks can be identified, analyzed, and contained using SAP Risk and Assurance Management (RAM)—a critical layer of protection beyond technical access controls.

entry.title: Enabling Joule Studio in SAP Build for existing Joule customers
entry.content:
Introduction

This post is intended for existing Joule customers who are looking to enable Joule Studio and start building custom Joule skills.

If you're enabling Joule for the first time—for example, with SAP SuccessFactors, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, or SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud—and want to activate Joule Studio alongside, we recommend starting with the Discovery Center mission: Establish a Unified Joule Instance. You should also check out the helpful blog series by my colleague @Diganta_Mandal, starting with Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build - Part 1: Provisioning Joule Studio.

On the other hand, if you’ve already enabled Joule with any of the SAP cloud solutions mentioned above and have an active Formation of type Integration with Joule (you can verify this in your BTP Global Account under System Landscape > Formations), then this blog will guide you through the steps to activate Joule Studio within your existing setup.


Motivation

We often receive questions from existing customers about how to enable Joule Studio. Some of the most common ones include:

  • Do we need to run the Joule booster again to enable Joule Studio in SAP Build?
  • Does SAP Build Process Automation need to be in the same subaccount as the Joule instance?

You’ll find answers to these and other key questions as you continue reading this blog post.

Prerequisites Before You Begin

  • Make sure your global account has the SAP Build entitlement, specifically the plan: build-default (Application).
  • Confirm that your SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS) tenant is included in your existing Formation.
  • Next, subscribe to SAP Build Process Automation with the plan: build-default (Application) in any subaccount of your choice. For guidance, refer to the Provisioning Setup section in Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build - Part 1: Provisioning Joule Studio. Note: You can skip the Joule Booster step in this case.

Important: Joule Studio is not compatible with tenants using the SAP Build Process Automation (plan: standard). A new subscription using the build-default plan is required.

If your SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant is not already part of your Formation and doesn't appear under System Landscape > Systems in your global account, you will need to manually add it.

Steps below for adding  SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant in your system landscape.

  1. Navigate to System Landscape > Systems and switch to the Service Owner View.









  2. Click on Add System and enter the details of your Cloud Identity Services tenant.


Steps to add SAP Build Process Automation in existing formation

  1. Go to your existing Formation of type Integration with Joule.

  2. Click Include Systems to launch the system inclusion wizard.
    Note: Your formation may already include systems like SAP SuccessFactors, SAP S/4HANA Public/Private Cloud, or other supported solutions.

    Answer to Question 1 (from the Motivation section):
    If Joule is already running with other solutions, you do not need to run the Joule Booster again to enable Joule Studio.


  3. In this example, a new subaccount named Joule Studio was created specifically for this purpose, with SAP Build Process Automation (plan: build-default) enabled in it.

    Answer to Question 2 (from the Motivation section):
    SAP Build Process Automation does not need to be in the same subaccount as the Joule instance.

  4. Select the Joule Studio subaccount and click Next Step.



  5. Choose Enable Capability Deployment, then proceed with Next Step.

  6. Review the summary and click Include.



    Your formation will begin synchronizing.



After a short while, if all steps have been completed successfully, the formation status will change to Ready.

You’re now set to start using Joule Studio to build and deploy your own custom Joule skills.



To continue, follow the next steps in the blog to:

  • Assign roles for Joule Skills developers. Refer Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build - Part 1: Provisioning Joule Studio.
  • Begin skill development using this blog post: Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build - Part 2: Developing and Deploying a Joule Skill
