entry.title: Enhancing Security in SAP Cloud Transport Management in SAP BTP - 1
entry.content:
About Me

Hare Krishna 🙏 I am an SAP BTP Cloud Architect sharing practical insights, solutions, and real-world experiences from the SAP ecosystem.

About the Blog

Node-Based Privileges for Granular Control

In modern cloud-driven operations, safeguarding production environments is non-negotiable. The latest enhancements in SAP Cloud Transport Management (cTMS) reinforce this with more precise access control, ensuring that sensitive transport operations stay firmly in the right hands.

What Changed — A Shift to Node-Specific Role Privileges

Traditionally, default roles in cTMS endowed users with broad-level access—often across all transport nodes. This "all-or-nothing" model presented a risk: one user could inadvertently or deliberately affect both development and production landscapes.

SAP has introduced node-specific privileges, enabling the assignment of roles tied to specific transport nodes only. In other words, you can empower a user to perform imports on the DEV node while blocking access to PRD—enforcing a principle of least privilege and securing production access by design.

Why Node-Based Access Matters

  1. Robust Access Governance
    By refining permissions at the node level, you can provide users only with the exact access they need—nothing more. This minimizes risk and helps enforce your internal controls effectively.

  2. Secure Production Environments
    Often, production subaccounts may contain highly sensitive data or critical business logic. Restricting transport permissions ensures that only trusted roles can push changes to production—reducing accidental errors or unauthorized updates.

  3. Cleaner Audit Trails
    When transports are performed, cTMS logs user actions with timestamps and node contexts. Node-based permissions make it easier to trace "who did what and where," boosting transparency and accountability.

  4. Better Separation of Duties
    Node-level restrictions support clean operational delineation—developers can be limited to DEV/QA, while release managers or operations teams handle PRD imports. This aligns with governance best practices.

How to Implement Node-Based Security in cTMS

Step 1: Define Role Templates and Node-Specific Roles

Start by leveraging SAP’s role templates, such as ImportOperator and TransportOperator, which serve as foundations for node-based roles. Create custom roles from these templates and attach node attributes to define the scope of operation.

Note:

  • When adding attributes to roles, it isn't validated that the transport node names actually exist in your transport landscape.

  • When you delete a transport node, you must manually update the corresponding role if necessary.

  • If you don’t add any attributes to a role, this grants unrestricted access to all nodes.

  • If a user has both restricted and unrestricted roles assigned, the restricted role takes effect.

Step 2: Build Role Collections

Group these node-specific roles into meaningful role collections—for example, “DEV-Importer,” “QA-Transporter,” or “PRD-Approver.” Role collections streamline user assignment.

Step 3: Assign Role Collections to Users

Within the SAP BTP cockpit under Security, assign the appropriate role collections to users who require node-specific transport capabilities.

Step 4: Conduct Import Operations

When users import transport requests, their permissions are evaluated against their assigned node-specific role collections—ensuring that only authorized users can act on particular nodes.

Real-World Example

Using the ImportOperator and TransportOperator templates, admins can custom-configure node-specific roles, assigning them per node and granting access only to designated users for each node. 

Current Architecture:

 

Define Role Templates and Node-Specific Roles

Create 2 roles using Import operator Role template: Non_Prod_Transport_Operator Role and Prod_Transport_Operator Role

Click on Create Role

Enter Role Name
In Configure Attributes: enter the exact node names to restrict this privilege to specific nodes assigned in this step

Select the Role collection from non Prod, Click on Finish after providing all the details

Similarly Create Role from Production Node
To restrict privileges to Production Node, Provide the Production Node name in Configure Attributes

Select Role collection for this role template

Click On Finish

Assign the Non Production Role collection to NonProd User

\

Assign the Production Role collection to Prod User

Login With Prod user to check: If received all the access to production node and no access to other nodes:

Got all the access to Prod Node

However ImportAll permission to Non Prod nodes (Just stay with me - we will fix it in few seconds).

Note on Role Restrictions

  • The TmsNodesTransportOperator attribute restricts authorizations only for TransportOperator tasks, but not for ImportOperator tasks that are also part of this role.

  • To restrict ImportOperator tasks as well, create a custom role using the ImportOperator template and assign the TmsNodesImport attribute.

  • This setup allows you, for example, to give a user permission to perform imports in all transport nodes, while limiting their ability to perform TransportOperator tasks to only specific transport nodes.

 

Create another role to restrict the privilege of import operator role to specific node

You can also provide a dummy node or virtual node or anything - this will make sure import all privilege will be removed from all other nodes except this one.

If you notice i have provided dev node, it will restrict the privilege to dev node(if a node exist with this name) else it will just make sure privileges of import all will be gone from all other nodes.

Now assign this permission to Prod User - This will make sure import all permission is removed.

We can see that permission is not visible now for prod user to any non prod nodes.

Similar issue is there for Non Prod user as well.

Now think of a scenario where No access is granted for non production user in Prod node however Import_all is granted, this can be a serious problem. Let's fix it for Non_Prod user as well.

Correct permissions in Non Production nodes.

However permission of import_all is granted in Prod node. Let's fix this

Assign the restrict import operator role collection created in previous steps to non prod user now.

Required permissions are intact in Non Prod nodes

 

ImportAll permission is removed from Prod node (Worked as expected)

 

Final Thoughts: Embrace Granular, Secure Transport Processes

The migration from coarse-grained default roles to node-based authorization is a strong leap forward in transport security for SAP BTP environments. By adopting these practices, you:

  • Minimize exposure of production systems

  • Align with compliance and audit requirements

  • Enhance separation of duties across functions

SAP’s node-level restriction model is a powerful tool for organizations aiming to strengthen their DevOps workflows while keeping production environments tightly controlled.

What’s Next?

In the next part of this blog series, we’ll focus on authentication and authorization enhancements—covering Single Sign-On (SSO) for UI access, automated role assignment with IAS/IDMS groups, and replacing Basic Authentication with OAuth2Password for destinations.

Stay tuned to learn how these features further strengthen your cTMS security!

entry.title: Enhancing Security in SAP Cloud Transport Management in SAP BTP - 2
entry.content:
About Me

Hare Krishna 🙏 I am an SAP BTP Cloud Architect sharing practical insights, solutions, and real-world experiences from the SAP ecosystem.

About the Blog

In the first part of this blog series, we explored role-based restrictions for SAP Cloud Transport Management (cTMS). In this second part, we focus on security enhancements in authentication and authorization that help organizations safeguard their transport operations.

We’ll look at three areas:

  1. Establishing SSO for UI access

  2. Role collection automation with IDMS groups

  3. Replacing Basic Authentication with OAuth2Password for destinations

1. Establishing SSO for UI Access

The first step in strengthening security is ensuring that administrators and operators (users performing import/export operations) access cTMS only through Single Sign-On (SSO).

  • Configure your subaccount to use IAS (or another corporate Identity Provider) as the primary IdP.

  • Disable the “Allow Identity Provider Login” checkbox for S-User IDs. This ensures users are not prompted to select an IdP at login and are automatically redirected to your corporate IdP.

  • Result: Direct SSO-based login, eliminating the risk of S-User credentials being used to access the UI.

✅Benefit: Centralized authentication, no fallback to S-Users, and seamless enterprise login for all UI-based operations.

Real Life Examples

In this scenario, i am using IAS as Identity provider. You can use IAS as proxy to any IDMS (Microsft Azure AD etc).

Establish trust with IAS tenant by clicking on Establish trust on top right corner.

Make sure you disable the "Available for User logon" option for SUSER ID. This will make sure it don't prompt users to select IDP. You can keep it enabled if you want to give option to users to login with SUSER as well.

Now Once user is setup in IAS, and required permissions are provided in BTP Subaccount,  Click on Go-To Application.

Enter the IAS UserID and Password - user which is setup for Cloud TMS login with required permissions

After successful login, you will be redirected to Cloud TMS screen.

 

2. Automating Role Assignments with IDMS Groups

Managing role collections directly for individual users can be error-prone and time-consuming. Instead, SAP recommends using Identity Directory (IDMS) groups to streamline access provisioning.

  • Map IDMS user groups to role collections in the BTP subaccount.

  • When a user is added to or removed from an IDMS group, the corresponding role collections are automatically assigned or revoked.

  • This eliminates manual steps, reduces the risk of incorrect assignments, and aligns user access with enterprise identity governance.

✅Benefit: Faster onboarding, reduced manual errors, and consistent access governance across your cTMS landscape.

Real Life Examples

We will be using IAS as identity provider and IAS groups for mapping. (Any IDMS groups like Azure AD can also be used for mapping). Let's see how it's done.

 Make sure IAS Application for subaccount is set to send Groups as attributes to BTP Subaccount in OIDC token

Create the Group for example ProdAccess

Assign the ProdUser to the group which we will use for authentication

Perform the Role collection mapping with IAS Group in BTP Cockpit. Make sure the Select the correct identity provider

Now perform the login with ProdUser

Login was successful, All the required privileges are automatically assigned to user

Prod permissions are assigned

Import all restrictions are also assigned properly

OIDC token contains the Groups attributes:

3. Moving from Basic Authentication to OAuth2Password

For backend communication (system-to-system), destinations in BTP must also be secured. Traditionally, Basic Authentication with S-User credentials was used, but this approach is less secure.

The recommended method is OAuth2Password with a technical user in IAS.

Steps:

  • Create a technical user in the Platform SSO IAS (the same IAS that manages subaccount logins).
  • Configure the destination in your subaccount to use OAuth2Password.
  • Add the origin property so the token request is routed to the Platform SSO IAS.

Enter the user and password as techincal userid and password created in previous step. Origin key should be of the Custom identity provider for Platform Users:

Origin key:

Destination:

  • Assign the required roles to this IAS technical user for the cTMS org/space.

⚠️Critical Note: Only the Platform SSO IAS (the one configured for platform-level SSO) can be used for this technical user. Other IAS tenants in your landscape cannot be used here. If you attempt to use another IAS, the destination may still validate during “Check Connection” but transport operations will fail (401 errors) at runtime.

✅Benefit: Removes reliance on personal or shared S-User credentials, strengthens system-to-system security, and enforces centralized authentication.

Conclusion

By implementing these three measures, you can significantly strengthen the security posture of SAP Cloud Transport Management:

  • Enforcing SSO for UI access ensures no S-User logins are used for administration.

  • IDMS group-to-role mapping simplifies and automates user provisioning.

  • Transitioning to OAuth2Password secures backend destinations with technical users in IAS.

Together, these enhancements reduce risks, improve compliance, and streamline secure operations across your transport landscape.

entry.title: Enhancing Security in Identity Authentication Service (IAS) with Certificate-Based Authentication
entry.content:
🔐Enhancing Security in Identity Authentication Service (IAS) with Certificate-Based Authentication

✨“Moving beyond Client ID & Secret — strengthening IAS with certificate-based authentication for enterprise-grade security.”

About Me

Hare Krishna 🙏 I am an SAP BTP Cloud Architect, sharing practical insights, solutions, and real-world experiences from the SAP ecosystem.

📘Introduction

In modern enterprise landscapes, Identity Authentication Service (IAS) plays a key role in securing access to applications and systems. Traditionally, system user authentication in IAS relied on Client ID and Secret (essentially a username and password mechanism). While simple to implement, it comes with inherent risks—🔑 password leakage and 🗄️ storage vulnerabilities.

To address these challenges, IAS provides the option to use certificate-based authentication, offering a stronger and more secure alternative.

 

 

 

 

 

 

⚠️Limitations of Client ID & Secret Authentication

Although widely used, Client ID and Secret authentication has drawbacks:

  • 🔑Password-like storage: Secrets need to be securely stored, often in encrypted vaults.

  • 🚨Leakage risk: Exposure in logs, code repositories, or integrations can compromise the system.

🛡️ Why Certificate-Based Authentication?

Certificate-based authentication strengthens IAS security by replacing secrets with a cryptographic key pair.

  • 🔒Stronger Security: Asymmetric encryption makes brute-force attacks impractical.

  • 🗝️ No password dependency: Eliminates risks tied to weak or reused passwords.

  • 🛑Leakage-resistant: Public certificate exposure is harmless without the private key.

⚙️How It Works in IAS

  1. 👤System User Creation: Generate a certificate instead of a Client ID and Secret.

  2. 🔑Public-Private Key Pair:

    • The public certificate is uploaded to IAS.

    • The private key remains with the consuming application.

  3. 🔍Authentication: IAS validates the presented certificate.

  4. ✅Access Granted: Secure communication is established.

🔗Real-World Use Cases for Certificate-Based Authentication

So when should you consider using certificate-based authentication in IAS?

This approach is particularly beneficial when:

  • 🌐You need to establish API-based connectivity with IAS from external tools or applications.

  • 🔧A system user is required for integrations, automations, or monitoring purposes.

  • 🛡️ You want to secure machine-to-machine (M2M) communication more efficiently than with Client ID & Secret.

In such scenarios, certificates ensure stronger trust and reduce credential management risks, making them ideal for enterprise-grade integrations.

🖼️ Real-Life Example: Configuring Certificate-Based Authentication in IAS

📂Understanding Certificate Formats Before You Begin

Before we jump into the actual configuration, it’s important to understand the different certificate file formats you may encounter during the process. This helps avoid confusion when handling files like .p12, .crt, and .pem.

✅Key Differences at a Glance

Format Contains Private Key? Contains Cert(s)? Encoding Typical Use
.crt❌No✅YesBase64 (PEM) or Binary (DER)Server certificate file
.pem✅Optional✅YesBase64 (PEM)Flexible container for certs/keys
.p12 / .pfx✅Yes✅Yes (can include full chain)Binary (PKCS#12)Import/export in apps, keystores

🔑Practical Flow in IAS Scenario

  • You generate a .p12 (PKCS#12) file → this includes both your private key and certificate chain.

  • From this .p12, you typically extract:

    • Private Key → required for secure client authentication.

    • Full Certificate Chain (.crt/.pem) → ensures trust and proper verification.

👉By understanding this, you’ll know what each file is for and why it’s being used in SAP IAS certificate-based authentication.

Step by Step instructions to perform the activity

Generate .p12 → extract private key (.pem) → extract full certificate chain (.crt/.pem) → upload public cert/chain to IAS (system user) → store private key securely in your app → enable client-certificate auth → test the API connectivity.

Login to IAS, Click on Administrators and create System User with required privileges

Click on Certificate

Provide CN name and password for certificate and click on generate - it will create a .p12 file

Save it.

Open Terminal and enter command (here API_Cert.p12 is the certificate name downloaded from IAS). Post this enter the required fields like passphrase etc.

openssl pkcs12 -in API_Cert.p12 -info

It will have private key and Full chain certificate, Copy the Private key in a text file and save it as .pem file

similarly copy the full chain certificate in a text file and save it as .pem

Upload the full chain certificate in IAS and save it.

Certificate is successfully uploaded in IAS

Let's test it using POSTMAN. Open Postman and go to settings -> Add certificate -> upload the certificate as shown below and provide URL of IAS and password

Perform a get operation to check if connectivity is working fine. You should receive 200 success message like shown below

📝Best Practices for Certificate-Based Authentication in IAS

  • 📆Track certificate validity: Default validity is 1 year — plan renewals in advance.

  • 🗄️ Secure private keys: Store them in HSMs or trusted key vaults.

  • 🔄Automate renewal: Prevent downtime due to expired certificates.

  • 📊Monitor usage: Continuously audit authentication logs in IAS.

🎯Conclusion

Switching from Client ID & Secret to certificate-based authentication in IAS is a major security enhancement. It reduces password-related risks, strengthens trust between systems, and ensures compliance.

By adopting certificates, enterprises can align IAS with modern security standards, making their environment more secure, resilient, and future-ready 🚀.

entry.title: Targeted User Sync: Filtering in SAP Cloud Identity Services
entry.content:
Introduction


In many landscapes, user replication between SAP Cloud Identity Services and target systems is configured to include all users by default. While this approach works for smaller environments, it often leads to unnecessary data transfers, increased synchronization times, and the replication of accounts that should not have access to the target system.
This article demonstrates how to implement filtering in SAP Cloud Identity Services to ensure that only users with specific group assignments are replicated. By applying this targeted approach, you can optimize replication performance, reduce administrative overhead, and strengthen access governance across your SAP landscape.

 

References

Before we begin, it’s important to note that IAS SCIM API version 2 offers several filtering capabilities as properties. This allows us to implement the necessary transformations more easily using property-based filters.

  • 📄See SAP Note 3575834 – IAS API V2 filter to read users from specific user groups in IPS and the official documentation: Source: Identity Authentication

You can find the complete list of Cloud Identity Services properties here:

  • List of Properties

For filtering, you can retrieve the required attributes via the Identity Directory API:

  • Users API (SCIM) – In the “Try out” section, enter your tenant details to test queries directly. We will cover this in more detail later in the article.

Step-by-step Configuration

  1. Go to Identity Provisioning → Source Systems in your SAP Cloud Identity Services admin console.

  2. Click the Properties tab in your source system configuration. Change the ias.api.version value to 2 to enable SCIM API v2 capabilities. Add the property ias.user.filter and specify your filtering rule. Save the changes.

    • In this example, a group-based filter is used:

groups.display eq "Test"

 

 

Extra – How to Test Your Filter Without Updating the Configuration

If you want to verify your filtering logic before applying it to your configuration, you can test it directly using the Identity Directory API – Try Out feature.

 

  • Go to the Try Out tab and select Add New Environment.

 

  • In the Configure New Environment dialog, fill in the following:

    • Tenant: Your IAS tenant name.

    • Display Name: Any name to identify the connection.
    • Starting URL: Leave as default https://{tenant}.{host}/scim.
    • Host: Your IAS host (e.g., accounts.ondemand.com).
    • Tenant: Your IAS tenant name.
    • Username
    • Password

 

 

 

  • Once the environment is configured, go to the Request section and enter your filter string in the filter parameter. For example:  emails.value eq "test@test.com"

 

Then click Run and review the Response section to verify that only the intended users are returned.

Conclusion

By leveraging IAS SCIM API v2 and property-based filtering, administrators can gain precise control over which users are replicated from SAP Cloud Identity Services to target systems. Implementing filtering not only improves performance by reducing unnecessary data transfers but also enhances security by ensuring that only authorized users are provisioned.

The Identity Directory API – Try Out feature offers a safe way to validate your filters before deploying them in production, allowing for quick iteration and testing without impacting live configurations.

With these techniques, you can streamline your identity management processes, reduce administrative overhead, and maintain a cleaner, more controlled replication setup across your SAP landscape.

entry.title: Use GitLab + Terraform for managing your SAP BTP and Cloud Foundry environments
entry.content:
This blog post is inspired by this brilliant blog post and this dev.to article.

Instead of GitHub we will be using GitLab as our CI/CD platform of choice 🚀 There are some minor differences though in the process when we compare the setup with GitHub which I want to point out. I will also provide you with a ready to use GitLab CI/CD pipeline and that you can use. In addition I'll explain our idea how we want to manage our BTP environment based on our experience managing google cloud by following basic security best practices like always following the principle of least privilege for each user.

How does it work?

Here is a brief explanation of the GitLab CI/CD workflow using terraform.

  1. A GitLab CI/CD pipeline is triggered (e.g., by a git push or a manual action).
  2. The GitLab OIDC Provider generates a JWT token for the running pipeline job. This token is made available to the job as a predefined CI/CD variable, such as $OIDC_TOKEN.
  3. This JWT Bearer token is used by the SAP BTP & Cloud Foundry Terraform providers in the Terraform scripts for authentication
  4. The Terraform providers send this token to SAP BTP and Cloud Foundry (UAA). These platforms, configured to trust your SAP Cloud Identity Service tenant, forward the token to it for validation.
  5. The SAP Cloud Identity Service validates the JWT's signature against the public keys (JWKS) of your GitLab instance's OIDC provider.
  6. If the token is successfully validated (based on the Enriched Token Claims settings, a user is found), the Terraform providers are authenticated and with the "mapped" user all subsequent calls will be made with this users authorization.

1. Create a new GitLab project

Create a new blank GitLab Project. The relevant content will be added later

2. Setup GitLab as OIDC provider in your SAP Cloud Identity Service tenant

First we need to setup GitLab.com as OIDC identity providers in the SAP Cloud Identity Service tenant.

  1. Login to your CIS tenant as admin.
  2. Create a new user group for all your GitLab users e.g. Name: GitLab CI/CD
  3. Go to 'Identity Providers' → 'Corporate Identity Providers' → Click '+ Create'.
  4. Use gitlab.com as provider name, select OpenID Connect Compliant as provider type. Click create
  5. Click on OpenID Connect Configuration. The Discovery URL for gitlab.com is https://gitlab.com/.well-known/openid-configuration 
  6. Now we also need a valid client for the authentication. Such an application has to be created in gitlab itself.
  7. Login to gitlab. Open a group or project that you want to use for btp deployments. In the menu select Settings -> Applications.
  8. Create a new application, give it a speaking name e.g. SAP Cloud Identity Service tenant <yourTenantId>, as Callback use https://<your-tenant>.accounts.ondemand.com/oauth2/callback, and select openid as Scope.
  9. Store the client id and client secret somewhere safe if needed.
  10. Enter the client id and client secret in the OpenID Connect Configuration.
  11. Add openid as scope and then save the configuration.
  12. Configure the token to user mapping in section Enriched Token Claims.
    Depending on your setup you need to define how you want to "identify" your users. You can find a list of supported claims from GitLab here
    Example:
    Claim: NameId
    Value: ${project_id}-${environment}@gitlab.com
  13. Follow the additional steps of the blog (Configure 'Identity Federation' to Restrict the GitHub IdP to GitHub CI/CD Users Only, Step 1.4)

Now just like in the blog we create a new user that follows our Enriched Token Claims format e.g. <gitlabProjectId>-prod@gitlab.com. Assign the user to the GitLab CI/CD group etc.

3. Maintain newly created user in SAP BTP with appropriate role

With the current setup the authentication would already work with the btp and cf providers but are still lacking the appropriate authorization for the new user.

Depending on the level of access (Globalaccount vs Subaccount) you need to assign the user manually and assign the role you need.

HINT: For some operations on subaccount level you might still need specific roles on global account level e.g. for reading assigned service plans


4 Setup the CI/CD pipeline + terraform code

Now we finally come to the fun part 😅

Our basic folder structure looks like this:

├── .gitignore
├── .gitlab-ci.yml
├── README.md
└── terraform
    ├── modules
    │   ├── btp
    │   │   ├── main.tf
    │   │   ├── outputs.tf
    │   │   ├── variables.tf
    │   │   └── versions.tf
    │   └── cloud_foundry
    │       ├── main.tf
    │       ├── outputs.tf
    │       ├── variables.tf
    │       └── versions.tf
    └── prod
        ├── .terraform.lock.hcl
        ├── main.tf
        ├── variables.tf
        └── versions.tf

We have a terraform folder, which contains all our terraform code. Inside the terraform folder we have a modules folder. One for btp and another one for cloud foundry. All resources that should be deployed in the specific environment will be described there.

Open the Spoiler to see the code for the btp folder

Spoiler
btp folder
main.tf
data "btp_subaccount" "subaccount" {
  id = var.subaccount_id
}

resource "random_uuid" "uuid" {}

locals {
  subaccount_name      = "${var.subaccount_stage} ${data.btp_subaccount.subaccount.name}"
  subaccount_subdomain = join("-", [lower(replace("${var.subaccount_stage}-${data.btp_subaccount.subaccount.name}", " ", "-")), random_uuid.uuid.result])
}

resource "btp_subaccount_environment_instance" "cloudfoundry" {
  subaccount_id    = var.subaccount_id
  name             = "${data.btp_subaccount.subaccount.name} ${var.subaccount_stage}"
  environment_type = "cloudfoundry"
  service_name     = "cloudfoundry"
  plan_name        = "standard"

  parameters = jsonencode({
    instance_name = local.subaccount_subdomain
  })
}
​

variables.tf

variable "subaccount_id" {
  description = "The subaccount ID."
  type        = string
}

variable "subaccount_stage" {
  description = "The deployment stage for the subaccount."
  type        = string

  validation {
    condition     = contains(["dev", "qas", "prod"], var.subaccount_stage)
    error_message = "The stage must be dev, qas or prod."
  }
}

outputs.tf


output "cf_api_url" {
  value       = jsondecode(btp_subaccount_environment_instance.cloudfoundry.labels)["API Endpoint"]
  description = "The Cloud Foundry API URL"
}

output "cf_org_id" {
  value       = jsondecode(btp_subaccount_environment_instance.cloudfoundry.labels)["Org ID"]
  description = "The Cloud Foundry organization ID"
}

versions.tf

terraform {
  required_version = ">= 1.10.0"
  required_providers {
    btp = {
      source  = "SAP/btp"
      version = "~>1.15.1"
    }
  }
}

Open the Spoiler to see the code for the cloud foundry folder

 

Spoiler
variables.tf
variable "cf_org_id" {
  description = "The Cloud Foundry organization ID"
  type        = string
}

variable "subaccount_stage" {
  description = "The deployment stage for the subaccount."
  type        = string

  validation {
    condition     = contains(["dev", "qas", "prod"], var.subaccount_stage)
    error_message = "The stage must be dev, qas or prod."
  }
}
​

main.tf

Spoiler
resource "cloudfoundry_space" "space" {
name = var.subaccount_stage
org = var.cf_org_id
}

data "cloudfoundry_service_plan" "html5_apps_repo_plan_cf" {
service_offering_name = "html5-apps-repo"
name = "app-host"
}

resource "cloudfoundry_service_instance" "html5_repo" {
name = "html5-repo-${var.subaccount_stage}"
space = cloudfoundry_space.space.id
service_plan = data.cloudfoundry_service_plan.html5_apps_repo_plan_cf.id
type = "managed"
}
outputs.tf is empty
versions.tf
terraform {
  required_providers {
    cloudfoundry = {
      source  = "cloudfoundry/cloudfoundry"
      version = "1.8.0"
    }
  }
}
​

And here is the code that will be accessed from our ci/cd pipeline. Many projects of us have different environments/stages (dev/qas/prod). There for we manage the main code in modules with all the ressources that will be deployed in each environment.

The environment/stages folders (dev,qas,prod) then basically just use the defined modules with some variables. This ensures that each environment contains the same resources (or differ a little bit depending on requirements e.g. a prod database setup might be different compared to dev/qas database setup).

Open the Spoiler to see the code for the prod folder.

 

Spoiler
variables.tf (all variable values are defined in the GitLab UI)
variable "globalaccount" {
  description = "The name of the global account in SAP BTP."
  type        = string
}

variable "subaccount_id" {
  description = "The subaccount ID."
  type        = string
}

variable "idp_origin_key" {
  description = "The origin key for the Identity Provider (IDP)."
  type        = string
}
variable "cf_region" {
  description = "The region for the Cloud Foundry environment."
  type        = string
}

variable "subaccount_stage" {
  description = "The deployment stage for the subaccount."
  type        = string

  validation {
    condition     = contains(["dev", "qas", "prod"], var.subaccount_stage)
    error_message = "The stage must be dev, qas or prod."
  }
}
​

providers.tf

provider "btp" {
  globalaccount = var.globalaccount
  idp           = var.idp_origin_key
}

provider "cloudfoundry" {
  api_url = "https://api.cf.${var.cf_region}.hana.ondemand.com"
  origin  = var.idp_origin_key
}

versions.tf (backend "http" {} is enough to manage the terraform state in GitLab)

terraform {
  required_version = ">= 1.10.0"
  required_providers {
    btp = {
      source  = "SAP/btp"
      version = "~>1.15.1"
    }
    cloudfoundry = {
      source  = "cloudfoundry/cloudfoundry"
      version = "1.8.0"
    }
  }
  backend "http" {}
}
main.tf
module "btp" {
  source           = "../modules/btp"
  subaccount_id    = var.subaccount_id
  subaccount_stage = var.subaccount_stage
}

module "cloud_foundry" {
  source           = "../modules/cloud_foundry"
  cf_org_id        = module.btp.cf_org_id
  subaccount_stage = var.subaccount_stage
}
​

 

 

 

4.1 GitLab CI/CD Pipeline

This is where the 🪄 magic happens. Let's have a look at the pipeline definition ( .gitlab-ci.yml file ).

Hint: In our environment we use GitLab CI/CD components. This avoids copy and pasting pipeline definitions and allows central maintenance including versioning and testing.

variables:
    TF_ROOT: $CI_PROJECT_DIR/terraform/$CI_ENVIRONMENT_NAME
    TF_STATE_NAME: $CI_ENVIRONMENT_NAME
    TF_VERSION: "1.12.2"

stages:
    - terraform prepare
    - terraform check
    - terraform plan
    - terraform apply

.job_template:
    image:
        name: hashicorp/terraform:$TF_VERSION
        entrypoint: [""]
    before_script:
        - cd $TF_ROOT
    variables:
        TF_HTTP_ADDRESS: "${CI_API_V4_URL}/projects/${CI_PROJECT_ID}/terraform/state/${TF_STATE_NAME}"
        TF_HTTP_LOCK_ADDRESS: "${TF_HTTP_ADDRESS}/lock"
        TF_HTTP_UNLOCK_ADDRESS: "${TF_HTTP_ADDRESS}/lock"
        TF_HTTP_LOCK_METHOD: "POST"
        TF_HTTP_UNLOCK_METHOD: "DELETE"
        TF_HTTP_RETRY_WAIT_MIN: "5"
        TF_HTTP_USERNAME: "gitlab-ci-token"
        TF_HTTP_PASSWORD: ${CI_JOB_TOKEN}
        TF_IN_AUTOMATION: "true"
    cache:
        key: "$CI_PROJECT_ID-$CI_COMMIT_REF_NAME-$CI_ENVIRONMENT_NAME"
        paths:
            - "$TF_ROOT/.terraform"
        policy: pull
    id_tokens:
        OIDC_TOKEN:
            aud: $CIS_TENANT_URL

"terraform prepare":
    stage: terraform prepare
    extends: .job_template
    environment:
        action: prepare
        name: prod
    cache:
        policy: push
    script:
        - terraform init
        - terraform validate
    resource_group: state-$CI_ENVIRONMENT_NAME

"terraform tf lint":
    stage: terraform prepare
    extends: .job_template
    image:
        name: ghcr.io/terraform-linters/tflint:v0.58.1
    environment:
        action: prepare
        name: prod
    script:
        - tflint --init
        - tflint --recursive

"terraform tf fmt":
    stage: terraform prepare
    extends: .job_template
    environment:
        action: prepare
        name: prod
    script:
        - terraform fmt -recursive -check

"terraform plan":
    stage: terraform plan
    extends: .job_template
    variables:
        BTP_ASSERTION: $OIDC_TOKEN
        CF_ASSERTION_TOKEN: $OIDC_TOKEN
    environment:
        action: prepare
        name: prod
    script:
        - terraform init
        - terraform plan -input=false -out="plan.cache"
        - apk --no-cache add jq
        - terraform show -json "plan.cache" | jq -r "( [.resource_changes[]?.change.actions?] | flatten) | { \"create\":(map(select(.==\"create\")) | length), \"update\":(map(select(.==\"update\")) | length), \"delete\":(map(select(.==\"delete\")) | length) }" > plan.json
    artifacts:
        name: plan
        paths:
            - "$TF_ROOT/plan.cache"
        reports:
            terraform:
                - "$TF_ROOT/plan.json"
    needs:
        - "terraform prepare"
    resource_group: state-$CI_ENVIRONMENT_NAME

"terraform apply":
    stage: terraform apply
    extends: .job_template
    variables:
        BTP_ASSERTION: $OIDC_TOKEN
        CF_ASSERTION_TOKEN: $OIDC_TOKEN
    environment:
        action: start
        name: prod
    script:
        - terraform init
        - terraform apply -input=false "plan.cache"
    rules:
        - if: "$CI_COMMIT_BRANCH == $CI_DEFAULT_BRANCH"
          when: manual
    needs:
        - "terraform plan"
    resource_group: state-$CI_ENVIRONMENT_NAME
    when: manual
    allow_failure: false

If you feel overwhelmed, that's ok 😅 I try to explain the most important parts.

We are using the official terraform image therefore we have to do some standard customization in the .job_template by setting some terraform variables for managing the state hosted on GitLab.

But most important is the definition of our token:

    id_tokens:
        OIDC_TOKEN:
            aud: $CIS_TENANT_URL

The variable $OIDC_TOKEN is a predefined, short-lived JWT token that GitLab automatically generates for authenticating with OIDC providers. This is a secure method that avoids storing static secrets. In order to use it with our Cloud Identity Service we need to adjust the aud property (audience) and use the URL of our Cloud Identity Service Tenant.

Now all we need to take care of assigning the value of the OIDC_TOKEN to the environment variables needed by the btp and cloud foundry terraform providers. We do this on the job level and assign the value of the OIDC token to the environment variables read by the terraform providers:

    variables:
        BTP_ASSERTION: $OIDC_TOKEN
        CF_ASSERTION_TOKEN: $OIDC_TOKEN

4.3 Terraform provider setup

Now we "only" need to setup the terraform providers for btp and cloud foundry to ensure that they use the JWT token for authentication. This is done in terraform/prod/providers.tf

provider "btp" {
  globalaccount = var.globalaccount
  idp           = var.idp_origin_key
}

provider "cloudfoundry" {
  api_url = "https://api.cf.${var.cf_region}.hana.ondemand.com"
  origin  = var.idp_origin_key
}

4.4 Define Terraform Variables for prod environment in GitLab

The last step is to maintain the needed variables for the prod environment in GitLab.

Open your project on GitLab and go to Settings -> CI/CD -> Variables

Now you can maintain all needed terraform variables. Important if to always prefix them with TF_VAR_variable_name.

By making use of the environment and managing the main resources inside modules, are able to deploy all needed environments/stages per project by using just one GitLab project 🚀.

This is the complete setup. Feel free to use it, adjust it, improve it, ... . I hope you learned something today and can benefit from the approach I am demonstrating here.

Outlook to our future approach

We want to follow our design principle that we have already successfully deployed in Google Cloud:

  • One central landing zone project which contains the overall global btp landscape and manages global trust, directories and subaccounts
    • The subaccount module will not only create the subaccount but also the "technical user" needed for the GitLab integration by utilizing the SAP Cloud Identity Provider Terraform Provider and assign this user to the appropriate role
    • In google cloud the creator of the project (=subaccount in btp), automatically became the owner of the project (full access). At the end of the project creation we always removed the landscaper user from the owner role to ensure that only the newly created project technical user is able to deploy ressources inside the project.
      We will try to setup the same approach in BTP. The landscape user should not be able to create any additional ressources inside a subaccount after the subaccount setup. This is the responsibility of the team working on the new project inside the subaccount.
  • Almost all platform users will only have viewer access to ensure that nobody does any changes by "accident". The terraform workflow sometimes takes a little longer compared to just a few clicks, but IaC brings you all the benefits compared to ClickOps
  • Every new BTP project will have one GitLab project for maintaining the infrastructure but also everything else needed for the project.
    • Right now we are migrating a CAP app from Google Cloud to SAP BTP (forced by the new license 🙄)
    • The terraform code and the CAP source code are all managed in the same GitLab Project. One team member can take of provisioning the infrastructure, while another team member is adapting the CAP code. CAP app deployment will then also be done using the GitLab CI/CD pipeline (and of course automated tests upfront to ensure we did not break anything).

Questions?

Feel free to leave a comment or contact me directly here or via LinkedIn.

entry.title: 🔐 Strengthening SAP BTP Security: SSO with Cloud Connector Using Token-Based Auth (Replacing SUSER)
entry.content:
About Me

Hare Krishna 🙏 I am an SAP BTP Cloud Architect sharing practical insights, solutions, and real-world experiences from the SAP ecosystem.

🌍Introduction

Security is at the heart of SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform) administration. Traditionally, basic authentication with SUSER credentials was required when connecting SAP Cloud Connector (SCC) with a BTP subaccount. While functional, this approach has critical drawbacks:

⚠️Static credentials stored in config
⚠️Weak auditability
⚠️Complex user/password management

With the adoption of token-based authentication and Single Sign-On (SSO) using a Custom Identity Provider (IdP), SAP now offers a smarter and more secure way of handling access. This blog explains how the shift strengthens security, simplifies user management, and eliminates the dependency on SUSER credentials.

🚀What’s New: Token-Based Authentication for the SCC ↔ Subaccount Link

Instead of sending an S-user + password when adding/maintaining the subaccount in SCC, you trigger an SSO flow: the subaccount’s trust configuration redirects to your Custom IdP, issues a short-lived token, and BTP validates it to complete the SCC connection.

Why it matters

  • ❌No static S-user secrets in SCC

  • ✅Short-lived tokens + centralized IdP policies/MFA

  • ✅Clean audit trail and easy revocation

⚙️Step-by-Step Configuration (Corrected)

Step 1 — Configure Custom IdP in the BTP Subaccount

  • BTP Cockpit → Subaccount → Security → Trust Configuration

  • Add/enable your Custom IdP (SAP IAS / Azure AD / Okta, etc.) for user logon

  • Ensure metadata/trust is correct (SAML/OIDC per your org standard)

Step 2 — Provision the Admin & Map Roles (in Subaccount)

  • Ensure the admin user exists in the subaccount and is mapped to the Custom IdP

  • Assign the Cloud Connector Administrator role collection (name may vary by tenant)

  • ⚠️Without this mapping, the token flow will fail when SCC tries to connect

Step 3 — Connect SCC to the Subaccount via Token-Based SSO

  • In SCC Admin UI → Subaccounts → Add / Maintain Subaccount

  • Choose token-based/SSO (not username/password)

  • The flow opens the BTP subaccount trust → redirects to your Custom IdP

  • Authenticate as the mapped admin; on success, BTP validates the token and SCC shows the subaccount as connected

Step 4 — Validate the Connection

  • Confirm SCC shows Connected (region, Subaccount ID, location ID as applicable)

  • Optionally verify in BTP cockpit (Connectivity / Cloud Connector view) that the subaccount link is healthy

Step 5 — Existing Subaccounts (Legacy) – Do It at Certificate Renewal

🔄For old subaccounts already connected with S-user: switch to token-based SSO during the certificate renewal window.

  • Keep the same subaccount; update trust to Custom IdP (if not already)

  • Re-establish the SCC ↔ subaccount link using token-based SSO (no S-user)

  • This upgrades security without spinning up a new subaccount

🛡️ Key Benefits

  • No S-user secrets stored in SCC

  • MFA & policies enforced centrally at your IdP

  • Auditable (IdP + BTP logs)

  • Lower ops overhead (no password rotations, fewer incidents)

🏗️ Architecture Flow — SCC ↔ Subaccount Token-Based SSO

[Cloud Connector]
│ (1. Connect/renew request to subaccount)
▼
[SAP BTP Subaccount – Trust Configuration]
│ (2. Redirects to Custom IdP for auth)
▼
[Custom Identity Provider (IdP)]
│ (3. User/admin authenticates → token issued)
▼
[SAP BTP Subaccount]
│ (4. Validates token & completes trust)
▼
[Secure Connection Established: SCC ↔ Subaccount]

Step notes

  1. SCC initiates the subaccount connection (add/renew).

  2. Subaccount trust hands off to your IdP.

  3. IdP authenticates the mapped admin and issues a token.

  4. BTP validates token; the SCC ↔ subaccount link is finalized—no S-user.

 

📸Real-Life Example (With Screenshots)

Here’s how this setup looks in actual environment( BTP trial account is used for performing this setup)

Create user in SAP BTP Subaccount, Provide Cloud Connector administrator privileges.

We will. be using IAS as custom identity provider. Create User in IAS as shown below:

Login to Cloud connector, Provide required details and update $SAP-CP-SSO-PASSCODE$ in Login E-mail section

📌Lessons Learned

  • The security move is about the SCC ↔ subaccount link, not just SCC UI logon

  • Provisioning & role mapping in the subaccount is critical for the token flow

  • Use the certificate renewal window to modernize legacy S-user connections with minimal disruption

❓FAQs

Q1. Do we still need S-user anywhere for this connection?
👉No. After token-based SSO is configured, the SCC ↔ subaccount link does not use S-user.

Q2. Which IdPs are supported?
👉SAP IAS, Azure AD, Okta, Ping, etc., via SAML/OIDC per enterprise policy.

Q3. Extra cost?
👉No new SAP license; enterprise IdP subscriptions/policies apply as usual.

Q4. Is this mandatory for all subaccounts now?
👉Not mandated, but it’s the recommended security posture going forward.

Q5. Must the admin user exist in the subaccount?
👉✅Yes. The user must be provisioned in the subaccount, mapped to the Custom IdP, and assigned Cloud Connector Administrator. Otherwise, the SSO/token step fails.

Q6. How do old subaccounts switch from S-user to token-based SSO?
👉✅Use the certificate renewal process to re-establish the link with token-based SSO—no new subaccount needed.

🎯Key Takeaway

Modernize the SCC ↔ subaccount connection with token-based SSO. You’ll remove S-user secrets, enforce corporate IdP controls (MFA, policies), gain clean auditability, and cut down operational toil. For legacy links, plan the switch at the next certificate renewal.
